summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2020 between FBI personnel and U.S. Attorney's Office contractors regarding the transfer and processing of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the US Virgin Islands. It details logistical challenges, data volume (~350 GB initial export), and technical issues with formatting the evidence for discovery. This document is a chain of emails from February to April 2020 between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and the FBI's New York office (NY FBI), coordinating the review and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The correspondence details significant logistical and technical challenges in processing over a million documents from devices seized in New York and the Virgin Islands.

persons.name: I. (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI forensic examiner coordinating the transfer of seized digital evidence from Epstein properties to the U.S. Attorney's Office. They discuss data formats, volumes, and timelines.

persons.name: (USANYS) [Contractor]
persons.context: Contractor receiving the digital evidence, asking logistical questions about delivery and data format, and working from home during the pandemic.

connections.description: Working together to transfer and process seized digital evidence from the Epstein case for discovery purposes.

events.title: Hard Drive Transfer Initiated
events.description: FBI examiner informs contractor that the hard drive containing seized evidence will begin its journey to them.

events.title: Discussion of Evidence Processing
events.description: Email exchange about the status of processing evidence from New York and USVI properties, noting challenges with newer Mac items in APFS format.

events.title: Methodology Disagreement
events.description: FBI examiner clarifies that the U.S. Attorney's Office is not 'processing' evidence but putting files into an e-discovery tool (Relativity) for taint review, a method they had warned would add months of work.

events.title: Previous Property Search
events.description: Reference to a July 2007 search of one of Jeffrey Epstein's properties, where 9 IDE hard drives were found and later discovered in his Manhattan apartment.

events.title: Evidence Review Coordination
events.description: Ongoing coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office and the FBI to inventory, process, and transfer digital evidence seized from Epstein's New York mansion and Virgin Islands properties, involving over a million documents.

locations: Virgin Islands (likely referring to Little St. James Island)
keyFacts: The FBI was preparing to transfer approximately 350 GB of initial export data from devices seized from Epstein's New York and US Virgin Islands properties.
Technical challenges included processing newer Mac devices with APFS file systems and ensuring email attachments were properly linked in the forensic output.

There was a noted disagreement or methodological issue: the U.S. Attorney's Office insisted on using Relativity for taint review, which the FBI examiner stated was not a forensic tool and added significant time to the process.
Logistical issues were compounded by the COVID-19 pandemic, with staff teleworking and reduced office hours affecting timelines.
The evidence encompassed a wide range of devices: Macs, Windows computers, iPhones, iPads, loose media (thumb drives, SD cards), cameras, DVRs, and servers.
Digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties included over 40 devices from a New York mansion and more than 25 devices from the Virgin Islands, including servers.

The FBI and U.S. Attorney's Office faced major technical challenges reviewing the data, including an inability to link emails to attachments and mismatched control numbers between load files and native files.
Evidence included 9 IDE hard drives from a July 2007 property search, found to be 3 copies of 3 drives.
The data transfer and review process was significantly hampered by the volume of material (over 1 million documents) and lack of proper inventory and labeling systems.
The correspondence indicates the case team was actively working on the investigation in early 2020, planning meetings and evidence reviews despite the COVID-19 pandemic.
